含义: 此 (cǐ) means 'this' or 'here' in Chinese. It is used to refer to something close to the speaker in space, time, or context.
字形: The character '此' consists of two parts: the left radical '止' (zhǐ), which means 'stop' or 'foot,' and the right component '匕' (bǐ), which resembles a spoon or dagger. Together, they form a character that visually suggests a stopping point or a reference to something nearby.
读音: The pronunciation of '此' is 'cǐ' in Mandarin, with the third tone.
字源: The character '此' originates from ancient Chinese pictographs. The '止' radical represents a foot, symbolizing a stopping point, while '匕' may represent a tool or marker. Together, they imply a reference to something close or immediate.
常用词组: 此时 (cǐ shí) - at this time
此外 (cǐ wài) - besides, in addition
从此 (cóng cǐ) - from now on
成语: 此时此刻 (cǐ shí cǐ kè) - at this very moment
此起彼伏 (cǐ qǐ bǐ fú) - rising and falling in succession
此消彼长 (cǐ xiāo bǐ zhǎng) - as one declines, the other rises
此一时彼一时 (cǐ yī shí bǐ yī shí) - times have changed
例句: 此时无声胜有声。 (Cǐ shí wú shēng shèng yǒu shēng.) - Silence speaks louder than words at this moment.
此地无银三百两。 (Cǐ dì wú yín sān bǎi liǎng.) - No silver is buried here (a proverb about over-explaining).
短故事: In ancient China, a man buried a pot of silver in his yard and then wrote a sign saying, 'No silver is buried here.' A thief saw the sign, dug up the silver, and left. This story illustrates the proverb '此地无银三百两,' which means over-explaining can reveal the truth.
A poet once wrote, '此时无声胜有声,' meaning that silence can sometimes convey more than words. This phrase is often used to describe moments of profound understanding or emotion.
诗词: 《静夜思》 - 李白 (Jìng Yè Sī - Lǐ Bái): '床前明月光，疑是地上霜。举头望明月，低头思故乡。' (The bright moonlight before my bed, I suspect it is frost on the ground. I raise my head to gaze at the moon, then lower it, thinking of my hometown.)

《登鹳雀楼》 - 王之涣 (Dēng Guàn Què Lóu - Wáng Zhī Huàn): '白日依山尽，黄河入海流。欲穷千里目，更上一层楼。' (The sun sets behind the mountains, the Yellow River flows into the sea. To see a thousand miles further, climb one more floor.)
